statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Shawn Marion had 24 points and 17 rebounds, and the Phoenix Suns capitalized on Milwaukee's 0-for-15 shooting from 3-point range to beat the Bucks 91-81 on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Bucks go oh-fer 3-point shooting
article.linkText: Bucks stumble to 0-for-15 3-point shooting in loss to Suns
article.story:
MILWAUKEE (AP) -- Even as Milwaukee misfired from 3-point distance, the Phoenix Suns credited their rebounding for their victory over the Bucks. Shawn Marion had 24 points and 17 rebounds, and Phoenix capitalized on Milwaukee's 0-for-15 shooting from 3-point range to beat the Bucks 92-81 on Tuesday night. Milwaukee, which entered the game with a league-best .398 shooting percentage from beyond the arc, had its eight-game winning streak snapped. The Bucks missed four 3-pointers in the first quarter, two in the second, nine in the third and six in the fourth. Phoenix coach Scott Skiles said strong rebounding was the key for the Suns, who were coming off a big win over the Timberwolves four days earlier. The Suns finished with 58 rebounds, including 20 at the offensive end. "We hung in there with Minnesota and then came in here and really cleaned the glass against these guys," Skiles said as the Suns won their second straight and for just the third time in 10 games. The Suns were playing for the first time since an overtime victory over Minnesota on Friday. Milwaukee, playing its sixth game in eight days, refused to use fatigue as an excuse for shooting 30-for-77 from the floor. "We couldn't get a flow going," said Michael Redd who scored 13 of his 16 points in the fourth quarter for Milwaukee. "They were a step faster, but that's no excuse." Losing the rebounding battle bothered Milwaukee coach George Karl. "Phoenix's guts are their offensive rebounds," Karl said. "We let them dominate us on the boards tonight. That's why we got dominated on the scoreboard." Penny Hardaway added 14 points and seven assists for the Suns, who outscored the Bucks 25-7 in second-chance points. Stephon Marbury scored just nine points and nine assists for Phoenix, which beat Milwaukee for the 19th time in 21 games. Jake Voskuhl had a career-high 13 rebounds for Phoenix. Joel Przybilla and Ervin Johnson each had eight rebounds for Milwaukee, which finished with 41 rebounds, nine offensive. Sam Cassell led the Bucks with 24 points. Milwaukee was again without Glenn Robinson, who missed his 13th straight game because of a left thigh bruise. Ray Allen, Milwaukee's leading scorer, shot 2-for-15 from the field and finished with 10 points. Allen failed to make a 3-pointer for the first time in 43 games. "Ray could never get into any type of flow and when he did come open, he and Timmy (Thomas) didn't make the 3s," Karl said. Tim Thomas, who has been starting in place of Robinson, missed seven 3s, and Allen missed five attempts. Hardaway said that the Suns were especially centered on stopping Allen. "Ray's a great player, but today we were well prepared to stay up on him," he said. "It was a tough job, but I was just focused tonight to not let him get any 3s." Cassell, who scored 13 points in the third quarter, hit a jumper to pull Milwaukee within 62-51 with 4:28 left in the period. That was the closest the Bucks got, and Phoenix maintained at least an 11-point lead in the final quarter. The Suns' reserves keyed the second quarter as they helped outscore the Bucks 29-1. Rodney Rogers had nine points, and Jake Tsakalidis and Tony Delk each added five. Marbury missed six jumpers before making three layups to help Phoenix build a 55-36 lead at halftime. The Bucks shot 7-for-19 in the second period and were hurt by their defense. The Suns had eight second-chance points in the second and finished with 18 put-backs in the first half.

Game notes
Karl said Robinson might scrimmage Wednesday and then possibly practice Friday. His status would remain day-to-day. ... Skiles in 5-0 against the Bucks. ... Rogers sprained his right ankle in the second quarter and did not return to the game for Phoenix.
